_header: It seems white and is red / It is quick and seems dead
Note: Cf. The ‘Long Charter’ of Christ, B Text, lines 117-20 (6650), and 5665.
_description: Rhyming lines on the Host — one quatrain

BLRoy17Axvi.Transcription:
Hyt semes quite and is redHyt is quike and semes dedeHyt is
                    ffleshe & semes bredHyt is on & semes tooHyt is god body &
                    no mo
BLRoy17Axvi.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Popular Prayers in Middle English Verse.” 
             Modern Philology
         36 (1939): 337-50: 344.
Davies,  Reginald Thorne. 
             Medieval English Lyrics: a critical anthology.
         London, 1963; Evanston, IL: Northwestern UP, 1964: 196.
Oliver,  Raymond. 
             Poems Without Names: The English Lyric 1200-1500.
         Berkeley, CA: University of California, 1970: 64.

DULCosVi12.Transcription:
Hit semeth whiȝth & hit is reedHit is quyk & semeþ
                    deedHit is flessh & semeth breedand veray god in his
                    godhed
DULCosVi12.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Popular Prayers in Middle English Verse.” 
             Modern Philology
         36 (1939): 337-50: 344.
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
